searchDocs.title: üîß Installation
searchDocs.content: üîß Installation info If you have already installed the requirements for the latest major version 1, you can directly skip to üíª Application installation. The installation process is divided in two segments: üìã Requirements üíª Application

searchDocs.title: üìö System recommendations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Prior to installation, ensure that your computer meets the following requirements:  A minimum of 4 GB of RAM for optimal performance.A multi-core processor (2 cores or more) for efficient audio processing.About 15 GB of free disk space for installation of dependencies.Sufficient storage space for audio files and processed data.For optional accelerated audio processing, we advise using an NVIDIA GPU.

searchDocs.title: üåê Operating Systems‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Refer to the following links for detailed instructions on installing requirements based on your operating system:   Windows Ubuntu macOS

searchDocs.title: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation Online
searchDocs.content: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation Online The üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module is accessibleonline. warning To access the audio features, you are required to serve the audio files independently. Use the cse_audio command to start the service easily. If the audio service is not provided, you will still be able to visualise your data minus the audio features.

searchDocs.title: C Compiler‚Äã
searchDocs.content: In order to install thehdbscan python package later on, a C compiler will be required.  You can install it on Windows through the Visual Studio Build Tools.

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è Procedure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Microsoft C++ Build ToolsClick on Download Build Tools to download the executableRun the executable (proceed until you get the menu Installing - Visual Studio Build Tools...)Check the first box for Desktop development with C++Click on Install (requires 6 Gb of disk space) Wait for the installation to complete. Once done, you can close the Visual Studio Build Tools window

searchDocs.title: Chocolatey‚Äã
searchDocs.content: We recommend using Chocolatey as a package manager to install the necessary requirements for the application on Windows.

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è Procedure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Click on the start menu (or press Win on your keyboard)Type PowerShellRight-click on the PowerShell iconSelect Run as Administrator (this will open a new elevated terminal)Navigate to Chocolatey installation pageScroll to find the installation commandCopy the commandPaste it in your elevated terminalPress Enter to execute the command. Wait for the installation to finish.Keep the terminal open for subsequent steps

searchDocs.title: Python‚Äã
searchDocs.content: For Python installation, use the following command:  choco install python3 --version=3.10.11 -y

searchDocs.title: üì¶ Other Dependencies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install the additional dependencies required by the application:   Node.js pnpm curl ffmpeg  Use the command below to install these dependencies:  choco install nodejs-lts pnpm curl ffmpeg -y

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the installed requirements, open an elevated PowerShell window (as described in the Chocolatey section) and run the following command:  choco uninstall python3 nodejs-lts pnpm curl ffmpeg -y

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Once completed, close your terminal and proceed to theinstallation of CSE.

searchDocs.title: üì• Download ~125 MB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Download coral-sound-explorer-1.0.18.zip ~125 MBExtract the archive (use Extract here)Open the folder coral-sound-explorer-1.0.18Proceed to the next steps

searchDocs.title: üîÆ Virtual Environment‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A virtual environment is established to manage Python dependencies.  It needs creation only once but can be activated multiple times.  tip You will need to repeat this step each time you open a new terminal session.

searchDocs.title: venv on  Windows‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Double-click on start.bat and wait for venv creation and activation.   Windows screencast

searchDocs.title: venv on  Ubuntu /  macOS‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Open a new terminal sessionType cd followed by a <space> and the path to the coral-sound-explorer-1.0.18 folder  Create venv‚Äã  Execute the following command to create a virtual environment:  python3.10 -m venv venv   Activate venv‚Äã  Run this command to activate the virtual environment:  . venv/bin/activate    Ubuntu screencast

searchDocs.title: üß© Modules ~14 GB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Modules constitute the components of CSE and occupy approximately 14 GB of disk space.

searchDocs.title: Modules on  Windows‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install all modules sequentially using the following command:  pnpm i; pnpm install:front; pnpm install:processing:windows   tip Use right-click to paste in Windows terminals.  tip For accelerated processing with a Nvidia compatible GPU, include additional dependencies: pnpm install:processing:cuda:windows

searchDocs.title: Modules on  Ubuntu /  macOS‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install all modules at once with this command:  pnpm i && \ pnpm install:front && \ pnpm install:processing   tip For accelerated processing with a Nvidia compatible GPU, include additional dependencies: pnpm install:processing:cuda

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the application and its dependencies, delete thecoral-sound-explorer-1.0.18 folder.

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next Step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Proceed to the üß© Modules documentation.

searchDocs.title: Oneliner ~500 MB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Execute this single command to automatically install all necessary system dependencies, consuming roughly 500 MB of storage:  /bin/bash <(wget -qO- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sound-scape-explorer/coral-sound-explorer/v1.0.18/bin/requirements-ubuntu.sh)

searchDocs.title: System Update & Essential Dependencies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This section ensures your system is updated and equipped with useful dependencies:   curl ffmpeg HDF5 Tools  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt upgrade -y && \ sudo apt install -y gcc curl ffmpeg hdf5-tools

searchDocs.title: Python‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install Python and related components:  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y software-properties-common && \ sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:deadsnakes/ppa && \ sudo apt install -y python3.10 python3.10-distutils python3.10-dev python3-pip python3.10-venv && \ curl -sS https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py | python3.10

searchDocs.title: Node.js‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install Node.js with the following command:  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y ca-certificates curl gnupg && \ sudo mkdir -p /etc/apt/keyrings && \ curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/gpgkey/nodesource-repo.gpg.key | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/keyrings/nodesource.gpg && \ echo "deb [signed-by=/etc/apt/keyrings/nodesource.gpg] https://deb.nodesource.com/node_20.x nodistro main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \ sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y nodejs

searchDocs.title: pnpm‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install pnpm with the following command:  sudo npm -g i pnpm

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã

searchDocs.content: The graph below details correlated dependencies between each data type.

searchDocs.title: Refresh configuration
searchDocs.content: Refresh configuration Digest your configuration file and copy all its information inside your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run all
searchDocs.content: Run all This command executes all the necessary steps for a complete campaign.

searchDocs.title: Run autoclusters
searchDocs.content: Run autoclusters This process automatically assigns numerical clusters (groups) to related intervals based on your configuration settings. These clusters will be visible in Visualisation as standard labels.

searchDocs.title: Quit
searchDocs.content: Quit danger While the üßÆ Processing module is running, you storage file will be inaccessible for üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation. When the üßÆ Processing module is active, your storage file remains open, making it inaccessible to other programs for reading purposes. Use this command to correctly close and release your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix This step initiates the required data required for performing autoclusters. As these data will not be accessed in üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation, you can utilise the Purge command to eliminate them from your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run digests
searchDocs.content: Run digests This stage involves taking aggregated data and generating derived data using digester algorithms.

searchDocs.title: Run reductions
searchDocs.content: Run reductions This stage involves taking the aggregated data generated by neural networks and reducing it based on your configuration reducers settings.

searchDocs.title: Run trajectories
searchDocs.content: Run trajectories This step involves computing the coordinates of the requested trajectories.

searchDocs.title: Run relative trajectories
searchDocs.content: Run relative trajectories This step involves computing the paths of relative trajectories.

searchDocs.title: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation
searchDocs.content: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation Implemented in TypeScript using Vue 3, the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module provides an intuitive and interactive graphical interface. This web application operates locally, eliminating the need for an internet connection. Users can input storage files generated by the üßÆProcessing module. It offers a comprehensive set of features for visualising processed results, empowering researchers to gain insights and make data-driven decisions. tip You can access this module online. üèÉ Getting started üìñ User Guide

searchDocs.title: üîó Compatibility‚Äã
searchDocs.content: While the web app is compatible with most browsers, we've encountered intermittent issues with Firefox on Windows 11 and Safari on macOS 14. For optimal performance, we recommend using Chrome.

searchDocs.title: üîß cse_vis Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This command initiates both the Audio and Front services.  In an active venv terminal, enter the following command to start both services (replace the path to your configuration file by dragging and dropping the configuration file icon into your terminal):  # Windows cse_vis C:\path\to\config.xlsx # Ubuntu / macOS (venv)$> cse_vis /path/to/config.xlsx   After pressing <Enter>, both services will launch, and your default browser will open.   Windows screencast  note You can alternatively use cse_viz as an alias for the cse_vis command.

searchDocs.title: üîß cse_audio Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Use the cse_audio command to start only the Audio service.  This can be useful in case you are using the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation online.  # Windows cse_audio C:\path\to\config.xlsx # Ubuntu / macOS (venv)$> cse_audio /path/to/config.xlsx

searchDocs.title: audio:front Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Simultaneously start both the Front and Audio services.  pnpm audio:front relative/or/absolute/path/to/audio/folder

searchDocs.title: audio Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start the Audio service on port 5531.  pnpm audio -- relative/or/absolute/path/to/audio/folder

searchDocs.title: front Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start the Front service on port 5530.  pnpm front

searchDocs.title: Run extractions and aggregations
searchDocs.content: Run extractions and aggregations This step involves extracting data from your audio files using either neural networks or indicator algorithms. Once the raw data is obtained, it's aggregated based on your integration settings. tip Optionally, you can choose to store these raw data using the persist option.

searchDocs.content: ‚ú® Extras Please find extra documentation in the sidebar.

searchDocs.title: üëã Introduction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Welcome to the official documentation for SoundScapeExplorer! This comprehensive guide is designed to help you navigate and harness the full potential ofSoundScapeExplorer. Whether you're new to SSE or a seasoned user looking for in-depth information, this documentation has everything you need to get started, optimize your workflow, and explore advanced features.

searchDocs.title: ü§î What is it for?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SSE is a powerful and versatile software environment designed for soundscape visualisation and quantification. It provides a robust platform for processing audio files, generating useful metrics, and presenting data through intuitive visualisation interfaces. Catering to bioacousticians and data scientists alike, SSE encompasses an extensive range of tools and capabilities to fulfil diverse user requirements.

searchDocs.title: üèÉ Getting Started‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This documentation is your gateway to unlocking the potential ofSoundScapeExplorer. Here's what you can expect:  üó∫Ô∏è User-friendly Navigation: Explore SoundScapeExplorer's functionalities and features effortlessly.üóÇÔ∏è Comprehensive Guides: Step-by-step instructions and detailed explanations to simplify your SSE journey.üí° Advanced Tips and Tricks: Optimise your workflow with expert-level tips and strategies.ü§ù Community and Support: Engage with the SoundScapeExplorer community, seek assistance, and contribute to discussions.

searchDocs.title: üìñ How to Use This Documentation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üîç Search Function: Use keywords or phrases to quickly find what you need.üö™ Navigation Bar: Explore different sections and topics via the sidebar or navigation bar.üîµ Interactive Elements: Throughout the documentation, find interactive components for better understanding and navigation.

searchDocs.content: Let's embark on this SSE journey together. Click on the sections in the sidebar to discover everything SoundScapeExplorer has to offer!

searchDocs.title: üß¨ Data inheritance‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The graph below details correlated dependencies between each data type.

searchDocs.title: Export dataframe
searchDocs.content: Export dataframe This command exports all intervals and their associated data to a .csv file.

searchDocs.title: Export mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Export mean distances matrix This command exports the mean distances matrix to a .npy file.

searchDocs.title: Purge computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Purge computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix This action involves removing computation data from your storage file since it won't be consumed in üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation.

searchDocs.title: Quit
searchDocs.content: Quit danger While the üßÆ Processing module is running, you storage file will be inaccessible for üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation. When the üßÆ Processing module is active, your storage file remains open, making it inaccessible to other programs for reading purposes. Use this command to correctly close and release your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Refresh configuration
searchDocs.content: Refresh configuration Digest your configuration file and copy all its information inside your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run all
searchDocs.content: Run all This command executes all the necessary steps for a complete campaign.

searchDocs.title: Run autoclusters
searchDocs.content: Run autoclusters This process automatically assigns numerical clusters (groups) to related intervals based on your configuration settings. These clusters will be visible in Visualisation as standard labels.

searchDocs.title: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix This step initiates the required data required for performing autoclusters. As these data will not be accessed in üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation, you can utilise the Purge command to eliminate them from your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run digests
searchDocs.content: Run digests This stage involves taking aggregated data and generating derived data using digester algorithms.

searchDocs.title: Run extractions and aggregations
searchDocs.content: Run extractions and aggregations This step involves extracting data from your audio files using either neural networks or indicator algorithms. Once the raw data is obtained, it's aggregated based on your integration settings. tip Optionally, you can choose to store these raw data using the persist option.

searchDocs.title: Run trajectories
searchDocs.content: Run trajectories This step involves computing the coordinates of the requested trajectories.

searchDocs.title: Run reductions
searchDocs.content: Run reductions This stage involves taking the aggregated data generated by neural networks and reducing it based on your configuration reducers settings.

searchDocs.title: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation
searchDocs.content: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation Implemented in TypeScript using Vue 3, the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module provides an intuitive and interactive graphical interface. This web application operates locally, eliminating the need for an internet connection. Users can input storage files generated by the üßÆProcessing module. It offers a comprehensive set of features for visualising processed results, empowering researchers to gain insights and make data-driven decisions. üîß Installation üèÉ Getting started üìñ User Guide

searchDocs.content: Run relative trajectories This step involves computing the paths of relative trajectories.

searchDocs.title: üëã Introduction‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Welcome to the official documentation for SoundScapeExplorer! This comprehensive guide is designed to help you navigate and harness the full potential ofSoundScapeExplorer. Whether you're new to SSE or a seasoned user looking for in-depth information, this documentation has everything you need to get started, optimize your workflow, and explore advanced features.

searchDocs.title: ü§î What is it for?‚Äã
searchDocs.content: SSE is a powerful and versatile software environment designed for soundscape visualisation and quantification. It provides a robust platform for processing audio files, generating useful metrics, and presenting data through intuitive visualisation interfaces. Catering to bioacousticians and data scientists alike, SSE encompasses an extensive range of tools and capabilities to fulfil diverse user requirements.

searchDocs.title: üèÉ Getting Started‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This documentation is your gateway to unlocking the potential ofSoundScapeExplorer. Here's what you can expect:  üó∫Ô∏è User-friendly Navigation: Explore SoundScapeExplorer's functionalities and features effortlessly.üóÇÔ∏è Comprehensive Guides: Step-by-step instructions and detailed explanations to simplify your SSE journey.üí° Advanced Tips and Tricks: Optimise your workflow with expert-level tips and strategies.ü§ù Community and Support: Engage with the SoundScapeExplorer community, seek assistance, and contribute to discussions.

searchDocs.title: üìñ How to Use This Documentation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: üîç Search Function: Use keywords or phrases to quickly find what you need.üö™ Navigation Bar: Explore different sections and topics via the sidebar or navigation bar.üîµ Interactive Elements: Throughout the documentation, find interactive components for better understanding and navigation.

Execute the command below to export the blog content to PDF:  npx docs-to-pdf \ --initialDocURLs="https://sound-scape-explorer.github.io/blog/index" \ --contentSelector="article" \ --paginationSelector="a.pagination-nav__link.pagination-nav__link--next" \ --excludeSelectors=".margin-vert--xl a,[class^='tocCollapsible'],.breadcrumbs,.theme-edit-this-page" \ --coverImage="https://sound-scape-explorer.github.io/img/logo.png" \ --cssStyle=":root{background: transparent}" \ --coverTitle="SoundScapeExplorer Blog 2024-2-22" \ --outputPDFFilename="SoundScapeExplorer-blog-2024-2-22.pdf"

searchDocs.title: üìö System recommendations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Prior to installation, ensure that your computer meets the following requirements:  A minimum of 4 GB of RAM for optimal performance.A multi-core processor (2 cores or more) for efficient audio processing.About 15 GB of free disk space for installation of dependencies.Sufficient storage space for audio files and processed data.For optional accelerated audio processing, we advise using an NVIDIA GPU.

searchDocs.title: üåê Operating Systems‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Refer to the following links for detailed instructions on installing requirements based on your operating system:   Windows Ubuntu macOS

searchDocs.title: üîß Installation
searchDocs.content: üîß Installation info If you have already installed the requirements for the latest major version 12, you can directly skip to üíª Application installation. The installation process is divided in two segments: üìã Requirements üíª Application

searchDocs.title: Homebrew‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Using the package manager Homebrew is recommended to install the application requirements.

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è Procedure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to brew.shFollow the installation instructions provided for HomebrewOpen a terminal to proceed with the next steps

searchDocs.title: üì¶ Dependencies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Execute the following command to install dependencies and update your path:   Python 3.10 Node.js pnpm C compiler curl ffmpeg  brew install gcc curl ffmpeg python@3.10 node@20 pnpm && \ echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/node@20/bin:$PATH" >> ~/.profile'

searchDocs.title: Xcode Command Line Tools‚Äã
searchDocs.content: info This step is optional. Additional context is needed.

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the installed requirements, open a terminal window and execute the following command:  brew uninstall gcc curl ffmpeg python@3.10 node@20 pnpm

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next Step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Upon completion, close your terminal and proceed to theinstallation of SSE.

searchDocs.title: üì• Download ~125 MB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Download sound-scape-explorer-12.3.0.zip ~125 MBExtract the archive (use Extract here)Open the folder sound-scape-explorer-12.3.0Proceed to the next steps

searchDocs.title: üîÆ Virtual Environment‚Äã
searchDocs.content: A virtual environment is established to manage Python dependencies.  It needs creation only once but can be activated multiple times.  tip You will need to repeat this step each time you open a new terminal session.

searchDocs.title: venv on  Windows‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Double-click on start.bat and wait for venv creation and activation.   Windows screencast

searchDocs.title: venv on  Ubuntu /  macOS‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Open a new terminal sessionType cd followed by a <space> and the path to the sound-scape-explorer-12.3.0 folder  Create venv‚Äã  Execute the following command to create a virtual environment:  python3.10 -m venv venv   Activate venv‚Äã  Run this command to activate the virtual environment:  . venv/bin/activate    Ubuntu screencast

searchDocs.title: üß© Modules ~14 GB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Modules constitute the components of SSE and occupy approximately 14 GB of disk space.

searchDocs.title: Modules on  Windows‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install all modules sequentially using the following command:  pnpm i; pnpm install:front; pnpm install:processing:windows   tip Use right-click to paste in Windows terminals.  tip For accelerated processing with a Nvidia compatible GPU, include additional dependencies: pnpm install:processing:cuda:windows

searchDocs.title: Modules on  Ubuntu /  macOS‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install all modules at once with this command:  pnpm i && \ pnpm install:front && \ pnpm install:processing   tip For accelerated processing with a Nvidia compatible GPU, include additional dependencies: pnpm install:processing:cuda

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the application and its dependencies, delete the sound-scape-explorer-12.3.0 folder.

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next Step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Proceed to the üß© Modules documentation.

searchDocs.title: Oneliner ~500 MB‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Execute this single command to automatically install all necessary system dependencies, consuming roughly 500 MB of storage:  /bin/bash <(wget -qO- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sound-scape-explorer/sound-scape-explorer/v12.3.0/bin/requirements-ubuntu.sh)

searchDocs.title: System Update & Essential Dependencies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This section ensures your system is updated and equipped with useful dependencies:   curl ffmpeg HDF5 Tools  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt upgrade -y && \ sudo apt install -y gcc curl ffmpeg hdf5-tools

searchDocs.title: Python‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install Python and related components:  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y software-properties-common && \ sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:deadsnakes/ppa && \ sudo apt install -y python3.10 python3.10-distutils python3.10-dev python3-pip python3.10-venv && \ curl -sS https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py | python3.10

searchDocs.title: Node.js‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install Node.js with the following command:  sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y ca-certificates curl gnupg && \ sudo mkdir -p /etc/apt/keyrings && \ curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/gpgkey/nodesource-repo.gpg.key | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/keyrings/nodesource.gpg && \ echo "deb [signed-by=/etc/apt/keyrings/nodesource.gpg] https://deb.nodesource.com/node_20.x nodistro main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \ sudo apt update && \ sudo apt install -y nodejs

searchDocs.title: pnpm‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install pnpm with the following command:  sudo npm -g i pnpm

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the installed requirements, open a terminal window and execute the following command:  sudo npm -g uninstall pnpm && \ sudo apt remove -y curl ffmpeg hdf5-tools nodejs python3.10-distutils python3.10-dev python3-pip python3.10-venv && \ sudo rm /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \ sudo rm /etc/apt/keyrings/nodesource.gpg && \ sudo apt update && \ sudo apt autoremove -y

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next Step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Upon completion, close your terminal and proceed with theinstallation of SSE.

searchDocs.title: C Compiler‚Äã
searchDocs.content: In order to install thehdbscan python package later on, a C compiler will be required.  You can install it on Windows through the Visual Studio Build Tools.

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è Procedure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Microsoft C++ Build ToolsClick on Download Build Tools to download the executableRun the executable (proceed until you get the menu Installing - Visual Studio Build Tools...)Check the first box for Desktop development with C++Click on Install (requires 6 Gb of disk space) Wait for the installation to complete. Once done, you can close the Visual Studio Build Tools window

searchDocs.title: Chocolatey‚Äã
searchDocs.content: We recommend using Chocolatey as a package manager to install the necessary requirements for the application on Windows.

searchDocs.title: üõ†Ô∏è Procedure‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Click on the start menu (or press Win on your keyboard)Type PowerShellRight-click on the PowerShell iconSelect Run as Administrator (this will open a new elevated terminal)Navigate to Chocolatey installation pageScroll to find the installation commandCopy the commandPaste it in your elevated terminalPress Enter to execute the command. Wait for the installation to finish.Keep the terminal open for subsequent steps

searchDocs.title: Python‚Äã
searchDocs.content: For Python installation, use the following command:  choco install python3 --version=3.10.11 -y

searchDocs.title: üì¶ Other Dependencies‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Install the additional dependencies required by the application:   Node.js pnpm curl ffmpeg  Use the command below to install these dependencies:  choco install nodejs-lts pnpm curl ffmpeg -y

searchDocs.title: üóëÔ∏è Uninstallation‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To remove the installed requirements, open an elevated PowerShell window (as described in the Chocolatey section) and run the following command:  choco uninstall python3 nodejs-lts pnpm curl ffmpeg -y

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Once completed, close your terminal and proceed to theinstallation of SSE.

searchDocs.title: üì£ Campaign
searchDocs.content: üì£ Campaign Creating a campaign is the first user step in using SoundScapeExplorer. A campaign enables the addition of audio files, label descriptions, and the definition of intervals and metrics. üèÉ Getting started üìñ User Guide

searchDocs.title: üìã Requirements‚Äã
searchDocs.content: To generate data, ensure you have:  Ran the üîß InstallationCompleted a configuration appropriatelyAn active Python venv in a terminal window  info Learn how to activate üîÆ virtual environments

searchDocs.title: üöÄ Execution‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Type sse followed by a <space>Type the path to your .xlsx file (or drag and drop file icon into the terminal)Press Enter   Windows screencast   Ubuntu screencast

searchDocs.title: üìù Examples‚Äã
searchDocs.content: # Windows sse D:\campaign\config.xlsx # Ubuntu / macOS sse campaign/config.xlsx

searchDocs.title: üßÆ Processing
searchDocs.content: üßÆ Processing Written in Python 3, this module harnesses machine learning and a range of algorithms to extract valuable metrics from audio recordings. The generated data is stored in .h5 format, allowing seamless integration with the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module and enhancing data sharing among users. üèÉ Getting started üìñ User Guide

searchDocs.title: üì• Download‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Download the default v12.3.0 configuration.

searchDocs.title: üè† Local‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Go to sound-scape-explorer-12.3.0/examples/campaignsOpen the new-campaign folderDuplicate and modify the default config.xlsx

searchDocs.title: Export computation UMAPs command
searchDocs.content: Export computation UMAPs command This command exports all computation UMAPs to a .npy file.

searchDocs.title: Export dataframe
searchDocs.content: Export dataframe This command exports all intervals and their associated data to a .csv file.

searchDocs.title: Excel configuration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: tip Paths referenced in the configuration are relative to this file.  tip You can automatically detect and add audio files.  tip Most column headers have documentation, available by hovering with mouse cursor.  The configuration is divided in multiple tabs:

searchDocs.title: Help‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This tab provides quick information.

searchDocs.title: Settings‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify your campaign settings in this tab.

searchDocs.title: Files‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify file paths, sites, dates, and labels in this tab.  tip Label properties must be prefixed with label_. We also recommend capitalizing them. Example: label_REPLICA

searchDocs.title: Bands‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify your filtering bands in this tab.

searchDocs.title: Integrations‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify integration intervals in this tab.

searchDocs.title: Ranges‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify dates and time spans in this tab.

searchDocs.title: Trajectories‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Specify trajectories in this tab.  warning label_property and label_value are case-sensitive!

searchDocs.title: Extractors‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configure extraction settings in this tab.  Refer to the ListExtractors tab for available extractors.

searchDocs.title: Digesters‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configure digesters (metrics) in this tab.  Refer to the ListDigesters tab for available digesters.

searchDocs.title: Reducers‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configure reduction settings in this tab.  Refer to the ListReducers tab for available reducers.

searchDocs.title: Autoclusters‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Configure autoclustering settings in this tab.  Refer to the ListAutoclusters tab for available autoclusters.

searchDocs.title: ‚è≠Ô∏è Next Step‚Äã
searchDocs.content: You can now generate your data using the üßÆ Processingmodule.

searchDocs.title: Purge computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Purge computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix This action involves removing computation data from your storage file since it won't be consumed in üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation.

searchDocs.title: Export mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Export mean distances matrix This command exports the mean distances matrix to a .npy file.

searchDocs.title: üìã Most Common Use Case‚Äã
searchDocs.content: For executing all metrics specified in your configuration file:  Choose Run AllWait for processing completion. When the menu reappears, the processing has finishedTo visualise your data, select Quit, then proceed to the Visualisation User Guide

searchDocs.title: üëâ Commands‚Äã

searchDocs.title: üß¨ Data inheritance‚Äã
searchDocs.content: The graph below details correlated dependencies between each data type.

searchDocs.title: Quit
searchDocs.content: Quit danger While the üßÆ Processing module is running, you storage file will be inaccessible for üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation. When the üßÆ Processing module is active, your storage file remains open, making it inaccessible to other programs for reading purposes. Use this command to correctly close and release your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run all
searchDocs.content: Run all This command executes all the necessary steps for a complete campaign.

searchDocs.title: Refresh configuration
searchDocs.content: Refresh configuration Digest your configuration file and copy all its information inside your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix
searchDocs.content: Run computation UMAPs and mean distances matrix This step initiates the required data required for performing autoclusters. As these data will not be accessed in üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation, you can utilise the Purge command to eliminate them from your storage file.

searchDocs.title: Run autoclusters
searchDocs.content: Run autoclusters This process automatically assigns numerical clusters (groups) to related intervals based on your configuration settings. These clusters will be visible in Visualisation as standard labels.

searchDocs.title: Run digests
searchDocs.content: Run digests This stage involves taking aggregated data and generating derived data using digester algorithms.

searchDocs.title: Run extractions and aggregations
searchDocs.content: Run extractions and aggregations This step involves extracting data from your audio files using either neural networks or indicator algorithms. Once the raw data is obtained, it's aggregated based on your integration settings. tip Optionally, you can choose to store these raw data using the persist option.

searchDocs.title: Run reductions
searchDocs.content: Run reductions This stage involves taking the aggregated data generated by neural networks and reducing it based on your configuration reducers settings.

searchDocs.title: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation
searchDocs.content: üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation Implemented in TypeScript using Vue 3, the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module provides an intuitive and interactive graphical interface. This web application operates locally, eliminating the need for an internet connection. Users can input storage files generated by the üßÆProcessing module. It offers a comprehensive set of features for visualising processed results, empowering researchers to gain insights and make data-driven decisions. üèÉ Getting started üìñ User Guide

searchDocs.title: Run relative trajectories
searchDocs.content: Run relative trajectories This step involves computing the paths of relative trajectories.

searchDocs.title: Run trajectories
searchDocs.content: Run trajectories This step involves computing the coordinates of the requested trajectories.

searchDocs.title: üîó Compatibility‚Äã
searchDocs.content: While the web app is compatible with most browsers, we've encountered intermittent issues with Firefox on Windows 11 and Safari on macOS 14. For optimal performance, we recommend using Chrome.

searchDocs.title: üîß sse_vis Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: This command initiates both the Audio and Front services.  In an active venv terminal, enter the following command to start both services (replace the path to your configuration file by dragging and dropping the configuration file icon into your terminal):  # Windows sse_vis C:\path\to\config.xlsx # Ubuntu / macOS (venv)$> sse_vis /path/to/config.xlsx   After pressing <Enter>, both services will launch, and your default browser will open.   Windows screencast  note You can alternatively use sse_viz as an alias for the sse_vis command.

searchDocs.title: üîß sse_audio Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Use the sse_audio command to start only the Audio service.  This can be useful in case you are using the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation online.  # Windows sse_audio C:\path\to\config.xlsx # Ubuntu / macOS (venv)$> sse_audio /path/to/config.xlsx

searchDocs.title: audio:front Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Simultaneously start both the Front and Audio services.  pnpm audio:front relative/or/absolute/path/to/audio/folder

searchDocs.title: audio Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start the Audio service on port 5531.  pnpm audio -- relative/or/absolute/path/to/audio/folder

searchDocs.title: front Command‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Start the Front service on port 5530.  pnpm front

searchDocs.title: ‚è≥ Loading a new  configuration‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Focus your terminal window and press CTRL+C keys to interrupt the module's services.  tip The üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è Visualisation module can handle only one configuration file at a time. You will need to stop current services in order to load a new one.
